SystemOutput:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

 Follow-up of chronic problems. 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

 Mr. Brian Mitchell is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for a follow- up of his chronic problems." It has been a little while since I last saw the patient. The patient reports he has been feeling out of sorts lately. He does not know if it is the change in the seasons or if we are just doing a lot of projects around the house and some construction on our own. He reports he is feeling lack of energy and lightheadedness. This has been going on for approximately 5 weeks. He denies any weight gain, fever, chills, dyspnea, shortness of breath, cough, or chest pain. Mr. Mitchell does report a 3/6 systolic ejection murmur, fine crackles at the bases bilaterally, and 1+ pitting edema of the lower extremities. He is taking his medications, and he states he is doing well with his diet. Regarding his congestive Heart failure, he has always been good about watching his food intake, but the past year has been chaotic as we began construction on his kitchen over labor day weekend, and not always the best food out. He notes he was unable to cook or prepare meals, so he ate out a lot and it kind of reeked havoc. The Patient endorses fatigue and dizziness when checked. He has not had any other symptoms of weight gain. 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

 • Constitutional: Denies fevers and chills. Endorses fatigue. • Cardiovascular: Endorses chest pain and slight cramps. • Respiratory: Deniesswelling, cough. • Musculoskeletal: endorses lightheadedNESS • Neurological: Endorse headaches, dizziness, and fatigue. 

EXAM

 • CV: Examination of the heart: Grade 3 out of 6 systolics ejectionmurmurmur, bilaterally. • Lungs: 1+ edema in the bilateral lower extremity. 

RESULTS

 Echocardiogram from 4 months ago shows reduced ejection fraction of 45%, as well as leaky valve and mitral regurgitation. 

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

 Mr.Brian Mitchell is an 58-years-old, male, with a history of congestiveHeart failure. • Medical Reasoning: He is retaining fluid. • Additional Testing: We will increase his Lasix to 80 mg once a day. • Patient Education and Counseling: I advised him to monitor his weight every day. He should also continue to report his blood pressures at home if they are elevated. • Specialist Referrals: I want him to report them to me in the patient portal if he sees they are getting elevated. Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

She states she was trying to change a light bulb and was up on a ladder and had a stumble and twisted her knee. This happened yesterday. She denies any other injuries. The pain is localized to the medial portion of her knee, over the medial meniscus. She has been putting ice and ibuprofen, but it does not help. She reports that she fell a couple of days ago, and she has hurt something inside of her right knee. She is taking a little bit of ice and putting ice on it, which has not really helped. She does have some tenderness over the right knee, as well as down her calves. 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

 • Constitutional: Denies calf pain. • Musculoskeletal: Reports right knee pain, right knee tenderness. 

PHYSICAL EXAM

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

 Ms.Thompson is a43-years-old-female who presents Today for an exam of the Right knee. Examination of her left knee: There are no obvious signs of fracture or dislocation. X-ray of the bilateral knees: No obvious fractures. No fluid or dislocations. No concerns with regard to hip or ankle. • Medical Reasoning: Looking at her exam and x-ray, she has tenderness on the medial aspect of her Right knee, which appears to be the source of pain. I recommended we place her into a knee brace and she will use crutches for the next 2 days. She will follow up in 1 week and we will see how she is doing at that time. • Additional Testing: We will order an MRI of the Left knee for further evaluation.  No known allergies.

 Bilateralpituitary adenoma.

He is symptomatic with clinical and radiographical evidence of optic chiasmal compression, therefore, surgical intervention to excise and decompress the pituitsary fossa is indicated. We will get this scheduled fairly quickly, so I do not want the patient to be alarmed. I will also get him set up today or tomorrow to have the visual field test. He may not be able to see the eye doctor until after surgery. We also have a pre-surgery visual field testing for comparison after surgery." The patient looks forward to his headaches going away.  Follow-up during neo AGIT chemotherapy.

 patient reports she is a 53-year-old female who has been going through a lot lately. She has a good support system.

I explained that we will continue with the current regimen of chemotherapy. She will continue to take Prednisone 40 mg daily for 5 days to help reduce inflammation. We also discussed lidocaine swish and swallow 4 times a day to help facilitate eating immediately after taking the prednisone. Continue with 40 grade 5 radiation doses at 40 mg per week until she completes complete imaging. At that point, we will need to repeat imaging and hopefully the tumor will shrink enough that we can surgically remove it. Patient Agreements: the patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

: weight, height, and weight look good. No fever. Cardiovascular - Examination of: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmur. Muscles are supple. No enlarged lymph nodes. HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

 Lawrence Taylor is a pleasant 53-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for an evaluation of right elbow Pain. The onset of his elbow pain began 1 week ago, when he was doing ceramics and doing pottery. He notes that he began to develop elbow pain, which he rates as the worst pain he has ever felt in his life. The pain is localized to the right elbow and does not radiate down into his shoulder. He denies any trauma to his arm or elbow. The patient locates his pain to the medial epicondyle. He states that he has never injured his right elbow before. The Patient rates his pain on a scale of 0-10, with 0 being the worst and 10 being the best. He estimates that his pain keeps him up at night. The patients has tried taking ibuprofen, which does not provide him with relief. 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

 Musculoskeletal: Reports right elbow pain; Denies shoulder pain. Neurological: Reports insomnia. 

VITALS

 All vital signs are within the normal limits. 

PHYSICAL EXAM

 MSK: Examination of the Right elbow: Positive for pain with pain to palpation. Pain to press against the flexed wrist. Pain with resistance against flexion of the left wrist. Tender tenderness of the medial Epicondylitis. 

RESULTS

 X-rays of the right elbows were obtained and reviewed today. These reveal no fracture or bony abnormality. 

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

 1. medial epicONDylitis, right elbow. 

PLAN

 After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to his current symptoms. I have explained to him that his x-rays did not reveal any signs of fractures. We discussed that the pain is likely caused by overuse and potential damage of the tendons that bend the wrist towards the palm of the elbow. I has recommended that the patient be placed into a sling and will wear the sling while he is awake. We have also discussed that he should apply ice to the elbow 3 times per day for 20 minutes, 3 times daily for the next 2 weeks. He should also take ib uprofen 600 mg, 500 mg, 6 mg, q.6 h with food. I advised him to hold off on any type of pottery for the NEXT couple of weeks. 

INSTRUCTIONS

 The patient will follow up with me in 1 week to check on his progress.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

 Emergency department follow up. 

MEDICAL HISTORY

 Patient reports history of hypertension. 

SURGICAL HISTORY

: Reports smoking cessation. 

MEDICATIONS

 Patient reports taking Cozaar 100 mg daily, Norvasc 5 mg once daily. 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

 Constitutional: Reports sleep like a rock. Denies chest pain. Cardiovascular: Denies dyspnea. Respiratory: Reports shortness of breath. 

VITALS

 Blood pressure: 128/72 mmHg 

PHYSICAL EXAM

 Neck - General Examination: No jugular venous distention. Cardiac - Auscultation of Heart: 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable. Lungs are clear bilaterally. Musculoskeletal - Examination: Trace edema in the bilateral lower extremities. 

RESULTS

 Echocardiogram reveals preserved ejection fraction of 50% and normal diastolic filling. Mild to moderate mild mitral regurgitation. 

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

 1. Hypertension. - Medical Reasoning: The patient's elevated blood pressure is likely caused by his uncontrolled dietary indiscretion and hypertension. - Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed the importance of watching his diet and watching what he is eating. I encouraged the patient to document his diet as well as his medication. He was advised to take his medication on time and see a nutritionist to help him get his diet on track. - Additional Testing: We will order a renal artery ultrasound to make sure that we are not missing anything. Patient Agreements: the patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

 Right-sided abdomen pain. 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

 Russell Bennett is a pleasant 69-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right-sided abdominal pain. The onset of his pain began several days ago, when he saw his primary care physician, who ordered a CT scan of the abdomen and told him he had a kidney stone. The CT scan revealed a 5 cm kidney stone located in the proximal right ureter. He has been taking Tylenol for pain, which has not been beneficial. He reports that his father has a history of kidney stones and has been able to pass them. 

MEDICAL HISTORY

 The patient reports that he has had kidney stones before, but this is taking a lot longer. 

SOCIAL HISTORY

 He is married with children. 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

 Constitutional: Denies fever, chills, or vomiting. Gastrointestinal: Reports nausea. Denies he is vomiting. Genitourinary: Reports pain in the right side of his abdomen below his ribs. Musculoskeletal: Reports right- sided abdomen pain, below the ribs. 

PHYSICAL EXAM

 GI/GU: There is no tenderness to palpation. No rebound or guarding. No peritoneal signs. There is positive CVA tenderness on the right flank. 

RESULTS

 The CT results from the abdomen scan ordered by the patient's primary care provider reveal a 0.5 cm right kidney stone in the distal proximal ureters. No evidence of hydronephrosis. 

ASSESSMENT

MENT AND 

PLAN

 1. Acute nephrolithiasis. - Medical Reasoning: The patient presents today with symptoms similar to acute kidney stones. His CT scan demonstrated a 1.5 mm kidney stone situated in the rectum. - Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed the importance of pushing fluids to help facilitate urination and peeing to help pass the stone. - Additional Testing: I will prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6 to 8 hours as needed for pain. He can continue to alternate that with some tylenol. I am going to give him a strainer that he can use to strain his urine so that we can see the stone when it passes. We will also order a basic metabolic panel, urinalysis, and a urine culture. 2. Ureteroscopy. - medical Reasoning; The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan. He will follow up in 1 to 2 weeks. If he is still symptomatic at that time, we will have to discuss further treatment such as lithotripsy or a ureTERoscopies.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

 Right foot ulcer. 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

 Nicolas Perez is a pleasant 53-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of a non-healing diabetic foot ulcers. The onset of his symptoms began 6 weeks ago when he put on a pair of shoes that were too tight. He first noticed a blister on the pad of the bottom of his foot around his heel. He then noticed a foul smell in his socks and noticed his dog was also smelling his socks a lot. He noticed that the blister had become unroofed. He called his primary care doctor, who started him on antibiotics about 6 days ago. He states that he never had any nausea or vomiting. He notes that his wife checked his temperature today and it was 99.7 point 7. He adds that at one point he had to put on an extra blanket in his bed because he had chills. The patient reports that after he started the antibiotics it started to feel pretty good, but he has now noticed that it has turned black around the outside of the wound and he is getting some cramping in his calf muscle. He has noticed that every time he pushes that he feel it all the way up to his knee behind his kneecap. He also noticed that he has been coughing a lot the last 2 days. He denies any pain at this point. 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

 Musculoskeletal: Reports right foot non- hematochezia. 

VITALS

 Slight fever. 

PHYSICAL EXAM

 MSK: Examination of the right foot reveals a necrotic wound on the heel. It is approximately 2 by 2 cm. There is sloughing of the tissue as well as what looks like cellulitis around the area. erythemia is also present. I do also smell the odor. Bilateral palpable pulses femorally and popliteal pulses are present. However, I do not recognize a palpable pulse dorsalis pedis or posterior tibial. 

RESULTS

 X-ray of the Right foot taken today in office does not reveal any evidence of osteomyelitis. 

ASSESSMENT

 Right foot nonhealing diabetes. 

PLAN

 After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to his current symptoms. I have explained to him that his blood sugar levels have been fluctuating over the last 3 to 4 weeks and that his A1c has been 6 to 7. We discussed that his sugars may have been as high as 5 to 6 hundreds at times during that time and that this may be what caused his wife to call the primary care physician. I has recommended that the patient continue his antibiotics therapy. We will order a test to check blood supply for the wound, and we will also perform a debridement today in the office. We may have to look at a culture and other antibiotic therapy as well. I am concerned about the redness that is moving up the leg as wellas the swelling and pain that he have in his calves. He will follow up with his endocrinologist to make sure that he is keeping his hemoglobin a1c below 7. Since we are going to be doing medication therapy with antibiotics and potentially some other medications, any other questions or concerns have been answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

 Right knee tick bite. 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

 Richard Taylor is a pleasant 80-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of a right kneetick bite. The onset of his pain began 1 week ago, however he denies any fever, chills, or other symptoms of fever. He does note that his knee has been warm on examination. There is full range of motion in the right knee, and on skin examination there is evidence of a bull's eye rash over the right patella. The patient states that he used to get tick bites when he was younger because he spent a lot of time out of the woods. He denies any other symptoms such as cough, shortness of breath, dizziness, or body aches. Mr. Taylor also notes that he has been working in the yard. He states that his last time he went hunting was a couple of weeks ago. 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

 Constitutional: Reports hypertension. Denies fevers. Cardiovascular: Denies murmurs, gallops or rubs. Respiratory: Reports clear auscultation bilaterally. Musculoskeletal: Reports right knee erythema and edema as well as an area of fluctuance overthe right knee. 

VITALS

 BP: 132/70. Heart rate: 60 bpm. Temperature is 98.4 today. 

PHYSICAL EXAM

 CV: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmur, gallop. 

RESULTS

 Lyme titer. Western blot. 

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

 1. Right knee ticks. - Medical Reasoning: The patient presents today with symptoms consistent with lyme disease. - Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed the nature of his tick bite and that he may have ly me disease. I advised the patient that it could be treated with oral antibiotics. He was provided with doxycycline 100 mg twice a day for 3 weeks. We also discussed the possibility of intravenous antibiotics due to the risk of lyme diseases that can cause problems on other organs such as his heart. - Additional Testing: We will order a hemoglobin A1c and continue him on metformin 1000 mg twice daily. 2. Hypertension. - medical Reasoning; The patient is doing well with his medication. His blood sugar levels are typically in the twenties, but there are some concerns with his recent blood glucose levels. - patient Education and counseling: I encouraged the patient to continue his lisinopril 20 mg once a day. Additionally, I recommended that we obtain a lipid panel to evaluate his cholesterol. -medical Treatment: We are going to start him on Doxycyclines 100 mg once daily to help with his Lyme disease. 3. Kidney function. -Medical Reasoning): The patient reports that his kidney function has been normal since his last visit approximately 2 months ago. -patient Education and counseling: I advised him that since his previous kidney exam did not reveal any signs of kidney dysfunction, we will obtain a basic metabolic panel to check on his kidney. - additional Testing: we will order an hemoglobin a1c to evaluate for possible kidney dysfunction. Patient Agreements: The Patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.
